Description: Fragment of nude child seated on an ornate wooden chair with cushion and feet resting on a pedestal. Originaly from an ithyphallic terracotta figurine of Harpocrates enthroned, one hand raised to his head. Two-piece mould made, and solid. Red-brown Nile silt with grey core, abundant mica and limestone inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Royal Museum of Art and History, Brussels. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Enthroned ithyphallic Harpocrates with one hand raised. This type was originally produced during the Late Period as a solid figure (British Museum GR 1973,0501.16 and in stone GR2011,5011.15; Cambridge Fitzwilliam, E.81.1914, Cambridge MCA, NA596) and was subsequently made hollow in the 3rd century BC like other Ptolemaic figures (Bolton Museum 1886.31.23; British Museum GR 1973, 0501.56; GR1973,0501.10; GR1973,0501.74). Parallel from 3rd century BC Ras el Soda, Alexandria (Himmelmann 1983, 47, 59, pl.23a; Adriani 1952). Adriani, A. 1952, Municipalité d’Alexandrie, Annuaire du Musée Gréco-Romain. Volume III (1940-1950), Alexandria. Himmelmann, N. 1983. Alexandria und der Realismus in der griechischen Kunst. Tübingen : E. Wasmuth.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DC.147) (Phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Musées Royaux d’Art et d’Histoire, Brussels
Acquisition notes: Purchased in Cairo by M. Jean de Mot
